utterances.sentences: No, sir. There`s notKRISTIN FISHER, CNN SPACE AND DEFENSE CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Most NASA astronauts know exactly where they were and what they were doing when the Columbia space shuttle disintegrated over Texas, killing all seven astronauts on board.

utterances.speaker: WOODY HOBURG, NASA ASTRONAUT
utterances.sentences: I was actually in high school. And I was -- I was actually in the shower.

utterances.speaker: STEPHEN BOWEN, NASA ASTRONAUT
utterances.sentences: I don`t usually turn on the TV to watch landings with my family, but that day I did. And after a couple of minutes,I kind of shoot them, said, hey, you guys go outside and play. And it was clear something was not right.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Crew six astronauts and cosmonauts return home to earth.

utterances.speaker: FISHER
utterances.sentences: NASA astronauts Stephen Bowen and Woody Hoburg returned to Earth in September after spending 186 days in space. Bowen, the commander of NASA`screw six mission to the International Space Station knew the Columbia crew. He worked the recovery operations and he was at NASA when the agency determined that it was a well-known problem with pieces of foam falling from the external tank and striking the shuttle at launch, that ultimately led to Columbia`s demise.

utterances.speaker: BOWEN
utterances.sentences: That -- that moment really, really hit home

utterances.speaker: FISHER
utterances.sentences: Since then, Bowen has been to space four times, including three shuttle flights.

utterances.speaker: BOWEN
utterances.sentences: Safety over the past 21 years, I think we`ve worked at it, but as a continuous process.

utterances.speaker: FISHER
utterances.sentences: When Bowen, Hoburg and two others attempted to launch for the first time in February 2023, on a SpaceX Falcon IX rocket and Crew Dragoncapsule, they scrubbed with just two minutes left on the clock due to an issue with igniter fluid.

utterances.speaker: BOWEN
utterances.sentences: We later learned that it was actually a NASA person in the room who had made the call not to do that. And I looking back at it and thinkingabout that willingness to say no, to stop, to say, we don`t need to launch today. We really appreciated that and that -- that`s an example of where we`ve moved a little bit past, hopefully, the things that have gotten us in trouble in the past.

utterances.speaker: FISHER
utterances.sentences: Now, NASA is attempting to return astronauts to the moon for the first time since the Apollo program. In January, the agency announced a 10-month delay to the first crewed Artemis mission, citing safety concerns. One area of concern, the Orion spacecraft heat shield. The same protective tiles that were damaged on Columbia.

utterances.speaker: BOWEN
utterances.sentences: You know, it was the heat shield for Columbia, but that`s not necessarily the next thing that`s going to get us, you know? It might besomething else that we haven`t thought of.

utterances.speaker: HOBURG
utterances.sentences: There is inherent risks and everything we do. And so we have to find ways to make sure that we understand what the risks are and mitigatethem, but then actually go fly.

utterances.speaker: FISHER
utterances.sentences: Kristin Fisher, CNN, Washington.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: ROSALES
utterances.sentences: All right, quiz time. You`ve got 10 seconds. What is the biggest museum in the world?Is it the Louvre Museum in France, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the Vatican Museums at the Vatican or Tokyo National Museum in Japan? The answer is the Louvre Museum in Paris. It covers more than 780,000 square feet and is home to about 38,000 pieces of art. And this next report, we`re going to take you to a museum where you can actually touch the art. That`s right. Mercer Labs Museum of Art and Technology in New York City is not your typical museum with velvet ropes and strict security guards. Nope. At this museum, the visitors are actually encouraged to come in and interact with the exhibits. That is because the Mercer Museum houses what is called experiential or immersive art. And as you`ll see in this report, it is easy to get lost in all the magic of it. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We redesigned this place 50 times until we find the right layout and the right energy and the right message behind every stepand everywhere you go in the space.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Each room touches your sense in a different way. The whole goal is for people to really walk through, experience those things,the sight, the smell, the touch, the feel.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The main hall, we have 26 projectors, so this room can be transformed to anything we want. You can see a film in 360. You canexperience sound in a completely new way. Coming in, you are part of the installation, you`re part of the art by walking in the space. I try to create a space that you`re standing there and you don`t know where is the ceiling, you know, where is the sky and where is the floor. We encourage people to come and touch the work and experience everything. You can touch everything. That`s the difference between what we are doing right here and other museums as well. I feel like today people need a little escape. I try to do something that can give hope.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
